comment._content: The ‘Stars & Stripes’ flag does not appear to be any one of the normal variations that would have been in existence before the end of the nineteenth century. The star arrangement differs from any of the established arrangements at that time!

comment.author: 40160780@N02
comment._content: Just looking at that poor little girl in the rags and bare feet  front left and the three boys in bare feet front right, makes me feel sad  to see them in the cold and mud.

comment.author: 15319761@N06
comment._content: Any chance this could be an American Boys' Brigade unit "on tour" in Ireland? I googled "Father Matthew Boys Brigade" and found reference to one such company in Indiana that marched in the dedication ceremony for the Indiana State Soldiers and Sailors' Monument in Indianapolis in 1902 and during "Hibernian Week" in Indianapolis in 1908: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86069180/1908-07-25/ed-...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
I think as Carol mentioned above, this is connected with the 1798 rebellion and is almost certainly part of the centenary celebrations that took place around Ireland in 1898, possibly a comemmoration of the Battle of New Ross. Waterford M.P. John Redmond was a major supporter of these activities.
Regarding the American flag, I think it might have something to do with Waterford born Thomas Francis Meagher who was commander of the Irish Brigade in the American Civil war and also acting governor of Montana when he died. A band named after him was formed in the city in 1885.
I also doubt if they marched all the way, it would have been much easier for them to take a steamer down the Suir and then up the Barrow to New Ross.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: The stars on the American flag seem to be offset, for an odd number of states (they aren't in straight lines for an even number of states), so that could possibly narrow down the date a bit. I like the idea about the Civil War era Meagher as above...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02/] I'm not sure if the American flags are much help in narrowing the date of the photo, they could have been aquired decades before this photo was taken. I'm pretty certain this is to do with the 1798 centenary, the American flags, I think, would have been carried to honour another one of Irelands heroes and to add to the festive nature of the event. There is another banner hidden behind the American flag in the foreground, would love to see what was on that.

a great crowd scene ! especially for the hats .....

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Would that be Father Matthew the Temperance priest?. All the band members are wearing pins in their lapels.The banner seems to have the American  shield  on it,(13 bars/stars),he had a huge following in the USA..

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
According to a Member of the Waterford History Group on Facebook, Michael O'Sullivan, this is,
"Father Matthews Boys Brigade , Waterford , setting out for the commemoration of the Battle of Ross, sunday 28th may 1898. The Waterford News reported that 230  members of the brigade bearing miniature pikes marched from the Temperance Hall in Parnell Street to the Quay, " where they paraded for the purpose of being photographed by Messrs. Poole." They were accompanied by a number of other groups including the Emmet Fife and drum band, and they all travelled to New Ross by steamer."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] That's fantastic, Paul, an exact date! Changing it immediately...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
And the outing to New Ross was only the half of it. This reports on events in Waterford the previous Tuesday... From Freeman's Journal Wednesday, 25 May 1898:
A magnificent torchlight procession was held last evening in Waterford to commemorate the beginning of the struggle of Nationalist Ireland against English tyranny in '98. It was first decided to fall in with the rest of Ireland, and celebrate the 23rd May at a meeting of the Thomas Francis Meagher Branch Ninety-eight Centenary Association, Waterford. The procession was entirely impromptu, and started at half-past eight, and the utmost order and enthusiasm prevailed. The procession started from the top of Manor street, down the Quay, up Thomas street, into Ballybricken hill, where it terminated. The demonstration was one of the largest seen in Waterford for a number of years. The procession was headed by the Parnell Brass Band, after which followed the Thomas Francis Meagher Fife and Drum Band, the Independent Brass Band, and at the end the Robert Emmet Fife and Drum Band. The banners of the United States and France, together with national flags, were carried. The Father Mathew Boys' Brigade, carrying miniature pikes, marched in the rere. Up the wide quay the magnificent proportions of the procession could be seen, and the torches gave it a most striking appearance. Huge bonfires were lighted on Mount Misery, an eminence overlooking the city, and the Temperance Hall and other places were decorated with lanterns. After the demonstration the people dispersed quietly to their homes.
P.S. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] the 28th was a Saturday. Should the date for this be Sunday 29th?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
Not sure about the date Carol, maybe it was reported in the Sunday edition but occurred on the day before, will try to find out for certain. 
That's a great piece from the Freeman's Journal and it seems Waterford would not have been alone, these celebrations happened all over Ireland in places associated with the rebellion.
